abstract: Suspected Al Qaeda leader Nazih Abdul-Hamed al-Ruqai dies in government custody from liver cancer just days before his trial in New York on charges related to 1998 bombings of two American Embassies in East Africa.
lead_paragraph: A suspected leader of Al Qaeda, Nazih Abdul-Hamed al-Ruqai, who was to be tried this month in the 1998 bombings of two American Embassies in East Africa, died in government custody after suffering from liver cancer.

byline.contributor: Benjamin Weiser reported from New York, and Michael S. Schmidt from Honolulu.
byline.original: By BENJAMIN WEISER and MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT

snippet: A suspected leader of Al Qaeda, Nazih Abdul-Hamed al-Ruqai, who was to be tried this month in the 1998 bombings of two American Embassies in East Africa, died in government custody after suffering from liver cancer.

headline.main: Qaeda Suspect Facing Trial in New York Over Africa Embassy Bombings Dies
headline.print_headline: Qaeda Suspect Facing Trial in New York Over Africa Embassy Bombings Dies
